message_1:
A company conducted a survey to collect data on the salary and years of experience of its employees. The data is given in the table below. The company wants to group the employees based on the similarity of their salary and experience using the k-means algorithm.

| Employee | Salary (in thousands) | Years of Experience |
|----------|----------------------|---------------------|
| 1        | 28                   | 3                   |
| 2        | 23                   | 1                   |
| 3        | 45                   | 7                  |
| 4        | 55                   | 10                  |
| 5        | 37                   | 4                   |
| 6        | 40                   | 5                   |
| 7        | 33                   | 2                   |
| 8        | 48                   | 8                   |
| 9        | 63                   | 12                  |
| 10       | 52                   | 10                  |
| 11       | 43                   | 6                   |
| 12       | 25                   | 2                   |

If the company wants to cluster the employees into three groups using the k-means algorithm, what would be the initial centroid points for the clusters, and which employees would belong to each cluster after the algorithm has converged?
message_2:
To apply the k-means algorithm, we first need to choose the initial centroid points for the clusters. There are different methods to choose the initial centroids, but for simplicity, we will use the random method. We will randomly select three employees as the initial centroids.

Let's choose employees 2, 5, and 9 as the initial centroids.

Centroid 1 (C1): (23, 1)
Centroid 2 (C2): (37, 4)
Centroid 3 (C3): (63, 12)

Now, we will calculate the Euclidean distance between each employee's data point and the centroids. The employee will be assigned to the cluster with the closest centroid.

After the first iteration, the clusters will be:

Cluster 1: Employees 1, 2, 7, 12
Cluster 2: Employees 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 11
Cluster 3: Employee 9

Now, we need to update the centroids by calculating the mean of the data points in each cluster.

New Centroid 1 (C1'): (27.25, 2)
New Centroid 2 (C2'): (45.57, 7)
New Centroid 3 (C3'): (63, 12)

We will repeat the process of assigning employees to the closest centroid and updating the centroids until there is no change in the clusters.

After the second iteration, the clusters remain the same:

Cluster 1: Employees 1, 2, 7, 12
Cluster 2: Employees 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 11
Cluster 3: Employee 9

Since there is no change in the clusters, the k-means algorithm has converged.

Final clusters:

Cluster 1: Employees 1, 2, 7, 12 (Lower salary and lower experience)
Cluster 2: Employees 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 11 (Medium salary and medium experience)
Cluster 3: Employee 9 (Higher salary and higher experience)
